steps.notes: Extract ilmenite from regolith; yields generated in process.

recipe_def.assumptions: Extraction yields ~0.6 kg ilmenite per 1 kg regolith input; tailings ~0.4 kg.
recipe_def.notes: In-situ ilmenite extraction from regolith; placeholder yields and mass balance.
recipe_def.name: Recipe for ilmenite extraction from regolith

steps.notes: Extract carbon reductant from carbonaceous regolith feedstock.

recipe_def.assumptions: Carbonaceous regolith feedstock available for small-scale carbon recovery.
recipe_def.notes: ISRU extraction route for carbon reductant; drying and sizing steps deferred.

steps.notes: Hall-Hroult electrolysis at ~960C. Very energy-intensive (15 kWh/kg)

inputs.notes: Aluminum oxide extracted from highland regolith
Flux to lower melting point (~90% recycled)

recipe_def.assumptions:
Hall-Hroult process produces aluminum suitable for structural applications.
Cryolite flux is 90% recyclable. Carbon anode consumption rate is 0.5 kg per kg aluminum.
Energy requirement: 15 kWh/kg is realistic for electrolytic aluminum production.
recipe_def.notes:
Aluminum alloy ingot production via Hall-Hroult electrolysis from alumina.

This is the standard industrial process for primary aluminum production.
Extremely energy-intensive (15 kWh/kg output) but enables local aluminum
production from lunar highland regolith.

Process chain from regolith:
1. Highland regolith (100 kg)  alumina extraction  12 kg alumina
2. Alumina (2 kg)  Hall-Hroult smelting  1 kg aluminum ingot
3. Therefore: ~17 kg regolith  1 kg aluminum ingot

Replaces placeholder recipe that incorrectly used generic melting/casting.

Wind copper coils for stator (and rotor if wound rotor) per design.

steps.notes: Cast aluminum link blank
CNC machine mounting surfaces and cable channels
Verify dimensions and structural integrity

inputs.notes: Aluminum alloy for casting or forming link structure

recipe_def.notes: Robot arm link manufacturing from aluminum casting with precision machining for mounting surfaces.

steps.notes: Cast aluminum gripper body housing
Machine gripper body and steel ball screw components
Assemble gripper: install bearings, ball screw, stepper motor, fingers
Test stroke and gripping force
Final inspection of gripper assembly

recipe_def.notes:
Manufactures electric parallel gripper from lunar materials + imported motor.

Design: 2-finger parallel jaw, 120mm stroke, 200N gripping force.
Aluminum body, steel ball screw, imported stepper motor and bearings.

Process:
1. Cast aluminum gripper body housing
2. CNC machine precision features:
   - Parallel finger slides with linear bearings
   - Ball screw mounting and nut
   - Motor mounting flange
3. Fabricate ball screw from lunar steel (10mm dia, 5mm pitch)
4. Assemble components:
   - Install 4 linear bearings for finger slides
   - Mount ball screw and nut
   - Attach NEMA 23 stepper motor (imported)
   - Install interchangeable jaw inserts
5. Test stroke, gripping force, repeatability

Inputs:
- 4.5 kg aluminum (4 kg final + scrap)
- 0.5 kg steel for ball screw
- 1 stepper motor (NEMA 23, imported - requires magnets)
- 4 linear bearings (imported in Phase 1)
- Fasteners for assembly

Lunar manufacturability: Body and ball screw from lunar materials.
Motor and precision bearings imported (require NdFeB magnets and precision balls).

Phase 2: Manufacture bearings from lunar materials with precision grinding.

Design reference: docs/labor_bot_design_memo.md section 3.6.1.

steps.notes: Cut steel tubing or angle iron for frame members
Weld frame structure with mounting points and reinforcements
Machine mounting holes, leveling surfaces, alignment features

recipe_def.assumptions: Welded steel frame from tubing or angle iron. Mounting surfaces machined for accuracy.
recipe_def.notes: Small machine frame for light machinery with welded construction and machined mounting points.

steps.notes: Cut power cables and signal wires to specified lengths (typically 10-50 meters total), strip insulation from conductor ends
Crimp connectors onto cable ends (ring terminals, spade terminals, Anderson connectors, D-sub connectors), solder signal wire connections
Route cables in harness layout, install strain relief components, bundle cables with cable ties or braided sleeving, label all connections
Continuity testing of all conductors, insulation resistance testing, verify connector integrity and proper mating

recipe_def.assumptions: Assembled cable harness for equipment power and signal distribution. 5 kg harness includes power cables (typically 8-12 AWG for 10-40A circuits), signal wires (18-22 AWG), connectors (power and signal types), strain relief components, protective sheathing, and cable management. Heavier duty than wire harnesses. Used in industrial equipment, machinery power distribution, and control systems.
recipe_def.notes: Manufacturing of assembled cable harness. Total fabrication time ~12.5 hours. Includes cable cutting and stripping, connector crimping and soldering, routing and bundling, labeling, and electrical testing. More robust than wire harness due to larger conductors and higher current capacity. Critical for equipment power distribution.

steps.notes: Assemble copper bus bars, breakers, terminal blocks, and indicator lights into board.

recipe_def.notes:
Local assembly route for power distribution board using copper bus bars and
off-the-shelf breakers/terminals. Replace imported breaker inputs with local
variants when available.

steps.notes: Cut frame plates/arms and mounting brackets.
Machine pivots, bearing seats, and actuator mounts.
Assemble arms, joints, bearings, actuators, and end effector.
Wire motors, encoders, limit switches, and controller.
Motion/accuracy check and safety interlock test.

recipe_def.assumptions: Light-duty delta robot; control electronics/coatings coarse.
recipe_def.notes: Local assembly route for delta robot v0.
